name: Avery Cortez
description: Avery is a 27-year-old amateur music producer in Austin who splits time between a daytime UX design job and late-night sessions in a compact, acoustically treated bedroom studio. Drawn to alt-R&B, lo-fi house, and groove-focused electronica, Avery is methodical about learning: setting weekly goals to finish short sketches, studying mixing fundamentals, and keeping a meticulous gear budget. They produce primarily in Ableton Live, leaning on a small but curated set of plugins, a 49-key MIDI controller, and a modest interface and monitors. Avery prefers buying used gear after exhaustive research, and resists impulse purchases by setting a 30-day “cool-off” rule. They catalog samples by key, BPM, and mood, keep field recordings from walks around the city for texture, and use reference tracks to shape mixes. A community-oriented collaborator, Avery trades stems online, attends local open-mic nights, and joins weekend jam circles to push past perfectionism. Their near-term goal is a self-released 5-track EP within a year, with one live performance using a minimal controller setup. Long-term, they want to develop a recognizable sonic signature—warm, tactile low end, dusty percussion, and evolving chordal layers—while maintaining sustainable creative habits and a healthy work-life balance.
example_behaviours: Schedules two focused 90-minute nightly production blocks with a short ear break between them
Keeps a Trello board for song ideas, arrangement tasks, and mix notes
Uses Ableton Live with a 49-key MIDI controller, Focusrite 2i2, Yamaha HS5 monitors, and Sennheiser HD600 headphones
Practices ear training for intervals and chord quality 10 minutes a day
Records city ambience and nature sounds with a handheld recorder to layer under drums
Crate-digs at thrift shops for vinyl to sample, logging potential sample points by timecode
Applies a 30-day rule before any new gear purchase and checks used listings first
Hosts a monthly virtual feedback circle with producers from Discord and Reddit
Studies mixing techniques like gain staging, subtractive EQ, and parallel compression with reference tracks
Attends local open mics and synth meetups to network and test works-in-progress
Tags and organizes sample libraries by BPM, key, and descriptive mood in a consistent folder structure
Sets quarterly goals (finish 12 sketches, 4 full arrangements, 2 mixed tracks) and reviews progress at month-end
